--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:

> Very simply at this stage I would say that the 'random' players 
> represent a more difficult challenge for NEAT. I did some tests 
early on 
> while I was coding the players where I evolved against just one 
strategy 
> and if I rememebr right, NEAT was able to evolve perfect 
startegies for 
> playing single opponents that were more (but not 100%) 
deterministic. 
> It's only when you give NEAT a range of different opponents and 
increase 
> the randomness that it starts to suffer.
> 

The problem with random players is not so much a problem related to 
NEAT but rather a problem for all of machine learning in general.  
It is the general problem of noisy evaluation: Something that 
actually isn't good can get a good evaluation if the random case 
chosen for it is lucky; conversely, it can look bad even if it's 
good if the random case is unlucky.  There is no methodological 
approach that I can imagine that can learn through too much noise, 
since it's not the learning algorithm but rather the evaluation that 
is inconsistent.  Thus, the best solution is to reduce noise when 
you can, which in practice means selecting a nice variety of cases 
that cover the space well, but that you can use over and over again 
consistently.  Hopefully that will offset the loss of generality 
from foregoing some randomness (a little randomness is usually not 
too terrible, though, but it's a art form getting the right amount).

ken
